item.title: Zambia Proposes Increased Number of Lawmakers as Elections Loom
item.description: Zambia plans to boost the number of elected members of parliament by more than a third, raising the prospect of a higher government wage bill at a time when the state is trying to conclude a debt-restructuring process.
item.dc:creator: Taonga Mitimingi

media:content.media:description: Hakainde Hichilema Photographer: Bernd von Jutrczenka/picture alliance/Getty Images

item.title: Sweden’s Surprise Economic Contraction Boosts Rate Cut Odds
item.description: An unexpected economic contraction in Sweden boosted expectations that the Riksbank will cut interest rates over the summer to support a rebound in output.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Duxbury

media:content.media:description: A factory floor in Sweden.

item.title: Inflation Dips Below 2% in Italy and Spain, Backing ECB Cut
item.description: Inflation in Italy and Spain eased to just below the European Central Bank’s 2% target, backing the case for interest rates to be lowered again next week.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Basteiro

media:content.media:description: Spain's consumer prices rose 1.9% from a year ago in May. Photographer: Angel Garcia/Bloomberg

item.title: ECB’s Panetta Suggests Inflation Is Almost Defeated in Euro Zone
item.description: European Central Bank Governing Council member Fabio Panetta signaled that inflation is nearly fully tamed, while cautioning that further interest-rate cuts require finely balanced judgments.
item.dc:creator: Flavia Rotondi, Alessandra Migliaccio, Sonia Sirletti

media:content.media:description: Fabio Panetta Photographer: Andrey Rudakov/Bloomberg

item.title: Turkey’s Economy Cools at Start of Year Despite Rate Cuts
item.description: Turkey’s economy cooled in the first quarter as high interest rates continued to weigh on activity despite a trio of early cuts by the central bank.
item.dc:creator: Beril Akman

media:content.media:description: Shoppers at the Mahmutpasha market in Istanbul. Photographer: Kerem Uzel/Bloomberg

item.title: Reform UK Chair Dismisses Worries About Cost of Tax, Spend Plans
item.description: The chair of Reform UK dismissed concerns that its plans to cut taxes and increase welfare benefits would rattle the bond market, casting the moves as part of a broader plan to “modernize the economy and get it growing again.”
item.dc:creator: Lucy White, William Selway

media:content.media:description: Zia Yusuf

item.title: UK Business Confidence Hits 9-Month High in Boost for Labour
item.description: A gauge of UK business confidence rose to a nine-month high, climbing back to a level not seen since soon after Prime Minister Keir Starmer first took power, as markets rebounded and trade tensions eased with the US.
item.dc:creator: Irina Anghel

item.title: BOE’s Bailey Urges Closer EU Trade to Reverse Brexit Damage
item.description: Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey urged the government to strike a deeper trade deal with the European Union to improve growth and “minimize negative effects” of Brexit.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick, Tom Rees, Irina Anghel, Francine Lacqua

media:content.media:description: Andrew Bailey, governor of the Bank of England (BOE), at the Monetary Policy Report news conference at the bank's headquarters in the City of London, UK, on Thursday, May 8, 2025. The Bank of England cut interest rates by a quarter point to 4.25% as Donald Trump’s global trade war weighs on UK growth, in a decision that split senior officials into three groups and was made before the US President hinted at an imminent deal to lower tariffs on British exports.

item.title: Kenyan Inflation Stays Below 5% for Longest Run in 15 Years
item.description: Kenyan annual inflation remained below the 5% midpoint of the central bank’s target range for a 12th straight month, the longest stretch since at least 2010, strengthening the case for another interest-rate cut.
item.dc:creator: David Herbling

media:content.media:description: Street vendors sell second-hand clothing on a shopping street in downtown Nairobi, Kenya, on Saturday, Dec. 5, 2020. Kenya is seeking a loan of as much as $2.3 billion from the International Monetary Fund under the lender’s extended fund facility. Photographer: Fredrik Lerneryd/Bloomberg

item.title: France Inks Deal With Singapore as Macron Courts Southeast Asia
item.description: France and Singapore signed a wide-ranging deal to enhance nuclear power and clean energy cooperation during President Emmanuel Macron’s visit to the city-state.
item.dc:creator: Philip Heijmans, Josh Xiao, Clara Ferreira Marques

media:content.media:description: France's President Emmanuel Macron speaks at a press briefing with Singapore's Prime Minister Lawrence Wong in Singapore on May 30, 2025. (Photo by Ludovic MARIN / AFP) (Photo by LUDOVIC MARIN/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Trump’s Tariff Options Slower, More Complex If Court Fight Fails
item.description: President Donald Trump’s administration insists his tariffs are here to stay, one way or another.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: Containers on a Cosco Shipping cargo ship at the Port of Long Beach in Long Beach, California, US, on Thursday, Feb. 20, 2025. The busiest trade hub in the US moved more containers last month than in any previous January, as importers rushed to bring in goods before widely anticipated tariff hikes from President Donald Trump. Photographer: Kyle Grillot/Bloomberg

item.title: Economists Warn ECB to Avoid Delaying Over Last Two Rate Cuts
item.description: The European Central Bank will lower interest rates twice more, according to a Bloomberg survey, but respondents warned it shouldn’t wait too long between those moves or investors will conclude that its easing campaign is already over.
item.dc:creator: Jana Randow, Harumi Ichikura

item.title: Tokyo Prices Rising Most in Two Years Keeps BOJ on Hike Path
item.description: Prices in Tokyo jumped the most in two years on surging food costs, keeping the Bank of Japan on track for another rate hike in coming months.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama

media:content.media:description: A customer shops for vegetables at a Marusan supermarket in Koshigaya, Saitama Prefecture, Japan, on Sunday, March 16, 2025. One year on from Japan’s historic rate hike, profits at its biggest banks are soaring to records, while price rises are forcing consumers to cut back and higher borrowing costs are fueling a political battle over how the government can rein in its outlays.

item.title: RBNZ Needs More Time to Decide on Path for Cash Rate, Silk Says
item.description: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand needs more time to assess the impact of global trade turmoil on the local economy before deciding on the appropriate path for the Official Cash Rate, Assistant Governor Karen Silk said.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Brockett

media:content.media:description: Karen Silk, assistant governor of the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ), speaks during a news conference in Wellington, New Zealand, on Wednesday, Feb. 19, 2025. New Zealand’s central bank cut interest rates by 50 basis points for the third straight meeting to help revive the ailing economy and signaled more easing in coming quarters. Photographer: Mark Coote/Bloomberg

item.title: RBA Pivots to Confront Global Downside Risks as Prices Ease
item.description: After a three-year campaign to rein in inflation, Australia’s central bank is now switching its focus to economic risks arising from the Trump administration’s tariff regime and mounting geopolitical upheaval.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

media:content.media:description: Michele Bullock, governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA), speaks at the Committee for Economic Development of Australia (CEDA) conference in Sydney, Australia, on Thursday, Nov. 28, 2024. Australia’s core inflation is “too high” to consider interest-rate cuts in the near term, Bullock said, reiterating that there’s still some way to go before prices return sustainably to target.

item.title: China Agrees to Resume Some Seafood Imports From Japan
item.description: China agreed to allow seafood imports from Japan pending some final procedural moves, Japan’s Agriculture Minister Shinjiro Koizumi said on Friday, in a step forward from Beijing’s blanket ban on the shipments following Tokyo’s release in 2023 of wastewater from a wrecked nuclear power plant.
item.dc:creator: Sakura Murakami

media:content.media:description: A consumer chooses a dish in a Japanese restaurant in Beijing on August 22, 2023. (Photo by Pedro PARDO / AFP) (Photo by PEDRO PARDO/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: PEDRO PARDO/AFP

item.title: Trump-Ishiba Call Gives Akazawa Momentum for Trade Talks
item.description: Japan’s top trade negotiator Ryosei Akazawa is heading into the latest round of trade negotiations with the US with some added momentum, following a phone call between Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba and President Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

media:content.media:description: Shigeru Ishiba and Donald Trump. Photographer: Kyodo News/Kyodo News Stills

item.title: Australian Retail Sales Unexpectedly Fall, More RBA Cuts Seen
item.description: Australian retail sales unexpectedly fell in April after three months of gains, led by a decline in clothing purchases and prompting traders to bring forward expectations for a third interest rate cut this year.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

item.title: Tariff Truce Keeps China-US Trade Flowing Across the Pacific
item.description: The ceasefire in the tariff fight between the world’s two largest economies is encouraging trade across the Pacific, holding up freight prices three weeks on, even as container bookings have begun to slow.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger, Katia Dmitrieva, Weilun Soon

item.title: Bessent Says US-China Talks ‘Stalled,’ Pushes for Trump-Xi Call
item.description: US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said trade talks with China are “a bit stalled,” and that a call between President Donald Trump and his counterpart Xi Jinping may be needed for the world’s two largest economies to reach a deal.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley

media:content.media:description: WATCH: China Hawk on the End Goal of US-China Relations.

item.title: Taiwan Says US Trade-Deal Push Still On Despite Court Ruling
item.description: Taiwan is continuing efforts to secure a trade deal with the US, a top official in Taipei said, even after a court blocked many of the tariffs that President Donald Trump has threatened to impose on other countries.
item.dc:creator: Yian Lee, Miaojung Lin, Yvonne Man

media:content.media:description: The Port of Keelung in Keelung, Taiwan.

item.title: Logan Signals It May Be Quite Some Time Before Fed Adjusts Rates
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas President Lorie Logan signaled it may take a while before officials know how the economy will respond to tariffs and other policy changes and thus how they should adjust interest rates.
item.dc:creator: Catarina Saraiva

media:content.media:description: Lorie Logan

item.title: Obscure Tax Item in Trump’s Big Bill Alarms Wall Street
item.description: Buried deep in the more than 1,000-page tax-and-spending bill that President Donald Trump is muscling through Congress is an obscure tax measure that’s setting off alarms on Wall Street and beyond.
item.dc:creator: Ye Xie, Liz Capo McCormick

item.title: Appeals Court Allows Trump Tariffs to Stay in Effect for Now
item.description: A federal appeals court temporarily paused a sweeping ruling against President Donald Trump’s global tariffs while it takes more time to consider the administration’s request for a longer-lasting hold.
item.dc:creator: Erik Larson

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump Photographer: Chris Kleponis/CNP/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Pressed Powell to Lower Rates in White House Meeting
item.description: President Donald Trump pushed Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell to lower interest rates at their first in-person meeting since the president’s inauguration, the White House said.
item.dc:creator: Amara Omeokwe, Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell

item.title: Fed’s Daly Says Policy in a ‘Good Place,’ Can Be Patient
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco President Mary Daly said monetary policy is in a “good place” to continue to bring inflation down.
item.dc:creator: Laura Curtis

media:content.media:description: Mary Daly, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, during the Macroeconomics and Monetary Policy Conference at the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco in San Francisco, California, US, on Friday, March 29, 2024. Inflation has slowed substantially since peaking in mid-2022, but the rapid progress seen late last year back toward 2% has seemingly hit a roadblock. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

item.title: ECB’s Kazimir Found Guilty of Bribery and Plans to Keep Job
item.description: European Central Bank Governing Council member Peter Kazimir was convicted of bribery and fined €200,000 ($225,380) in a ruling that will cause embarrassment to the Frankfurt institution.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Hornak

media:content.media:description: Peter Kazimir Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: The Economic Benefits of Paying Workers to Move
item.description: A new study finds that Tulsa’s effort to lure remote workers with $10,000 has returned four times that investment back into the local economy.
item.dc:creator: Rthvika Suvarna, Fola Akinnibi

media:content.media:description: Tulsa is the second-largest city in the state of Oklahoma and 47th-most populous city in the United States.

item.title: US May Take Trump Tariff Case to Supreme Court on Friday
item.description: The Trump administration said it would ask the US Supreme Court to intervene as soon as Friday if a federal appeals court doesn’t immediately put on hold a decision finding that most of the president’s tariffs are illegal.
item.dc:creator: Erik Larson, Greg Stohr

media:content.media:description: The US Supreme Court in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, Jan. 10, 2025. Supreme Court justices signaled they are likely to uphold a law that would ban the popular social media platform TikTok in the US if it isn’t sold by its Chinese parent company by Jan. 19.

item.title: Banxico See More Rate Cuts After Mexico Skirted Recession
item.description: Mexico’s central bank expects to continue to ease monetary policy gradually after the economy narrowly avoided recession.
item.dc:creator: Maya Averbuch, Alex Vasquez

media:content.media:description: Mexico's central bank headquarters, the Banco de Mexico, in Mexico City, Mexico, on Tuesday, March 4, 2025. The Mexican peso slumped after US President Donald Trump imposed new import tariffs against the country, though other developing-nation currencies held their own amid concerns about the impact of the escalating trade war on growth in the world's largest economy.
